comment_0: "Light of my life, fire of my loins," are the opening words to 'Lolita,' if you've read it you'll realise that the song is pretty much like a soundtrack to the book. The book is a classic and LDR has put a nice 'gangsta' spin on it. My favourite song of hers by far...
comment_1: Another classic Lana love song, even more perverse than her other songs. She wants to be loved the possessive way Humbert Humbert loves Lolita, a twisted love of ownership and worship, where Lover Sugar Daddy owns her like a possession and worships her sexually. As per usual with Lana, the spending of money on her equates to love, because Lana likes the masochistic delight of being owned and bought by another person. Giving herself up to be owned by another is the declaration of the greatest possible love for Lana.
comment_2: I always assumed it was about being in love with a man who really was only with her for her beauty and sex, honestly. He sounds like he's involved in some kind of illegal activity, possibly drugs.
comment_3:
I have the digital booklet! :D 

"Up Bacardi chasers" is "of Bacardi chasers" (and the second chorus is "Now we're off to the races, cases" instead of "Now we're off to the races, races")

"Glass film" is "glass room"

"Fume" is "fumes"

"Tell me you want me" is "tell me you own me"

"Your faces, shameless" is actually "your face is shameless"

"Harlet" is spelled "harlot" (sorry I had to throw that in it was just bothering me :3 )

"The law" is "the Lord" (not literally!)

"I'll never leave you" is "I'd never leave you"

"Pay us" is actually "chaos"

"'Cause you know we'll race this" is "casino oasis"

"Spit" is "spin"

Okay all done.
comment_4: There is such a big Lolita theme on this record, I LOVE it! :) The light of my life, fire of my lions is taken straight from the book :)
comment_5:
This song is obviously about the classic "Lolita", by Vladimir Nabokov as the opening line to the book is "Lolita, light of my life, fire of my loins. My sin, my soul." Lana has described her style as "Lolita got lost in The Hood," meaning that she has probably read the book, and based "Off To The Races" on it. I believe she uses the book as an overall metaphor for her own life, or it could just possible weave between the two. I think that when she sings 'And I'm off to the races, cases
of Bacardi chasers, chasin' me all over town', she is using it as a metaphor. When Lana was younger she had problems with alchohol and I think she is saying that the thought of a drink follows her around, like Humbert did Lolita.
comment_6:
This whole song is about the book and film Lana Del Rey claims she loves: Lolita. 
If you watch the film it will all make sense and it's a pet peeve of mine people that claim they love this song without having any idea what its about and just thinking it's another love story. It's more than that as in this song Lana sings as if she is Lolita even from her voice which she makes very child like throughout, even the words are sung from the perspective of a child such as the bit where she almost breaks down about her feelings and sings 

"My old man is a thief, and
I'm gonna stay and pray with him till the end
 But I trust in the decision of the LORD,
To watch over us
Take him when he may, if he may
I'm not afraid to say
That I'd die without him
Who else is gonna put up with me this way
I need you, I breathe you, I'D never leave you
They would rue the day, I was alone without you

You're lying with your gold chain on
Cigar hanging from your lips
I said hon' you never looked so beautiful
As you do now my man

This bit is very childlike as if she is throwing down all her feelings like she's probbably heard about in the movies and its all very desperate like you get over your first love and you think it will never end. It also highlights how much older Lolita (Lana Del Rey) thinks she is by saying all this.

Absolutely love.
comment_7:
I think the speaker in this song is Carmen, from that later track on her album. The songs might just have similar themes but be completely different, but my interpretation is that both Carmen and the speaker in this song are prostitutes. I think "Carmen" is about the difficulties of a life of prostitution from an outsider's perspective, but "Off to the Races" is Carmen's defense for her lifestyle...she believes (or just tells herself) that she's really living the good life and that her pimp legitimately cares about her and takes care of her.

Just a thought :) I had been wondering about this when I heard some similarities in the two songs, ex: "slipping on my red dress, putting on my makeup" from this song and "put your red dress on, put your lipstick on" from "Carmen."
comment_8: Hate to be the annoying lyric correcting guy but: *Cipriani's basement, not 'trippy on his basement'.

comment_11:
Lana's style is described as "Lolita lost in the hood," so she's obviously familiar with the book Lolita by Vladimir Nabokov... "My old man is a bad man, but I can't deny the way he holds my hand.." Lolita is all about a man who has a sexual relationship with his stepdaughter...
In the chorus: "And I'm off to the races, cases, of Bacardi chasers, chasing me all over town-" Lana has admitted to having an alcohol problem in school, she's written about it in songs like Carmen or This is What Makes Us Girls.. But it could also be metaphorical for the way Dolores (Lolita)'s stepfather follows her around.
"'Cuz he knows I'm wasted--" in the book, Lolita's stepfather makes her fall asleep with a medicine, so he can get sexual favors...
This song is very much about Lolita, but the way she wrote it is so amazing, it is a metaphor for her life, basically.
comment_12: As many people have said, this song refers to the novel, Lolita, by Nabokov. The line "light of my life, fire of my loins" comes directly from the book, and is actually the first line. In the novel, Lolita originally has a chidlish crush on the narrator, Humbert, and he describes her teasing him. The segment about the swimming pool is in the novel, as Humbert watches Lolita many times as she is swimming. He also calls her is starlet at times. Humbert is arrested in the end of the novel, and is referenced in this song. Lana obviously weaves in some of her own twists, and sings it from the point of view of Lolita. But it all stems from that book, and the movie.
comment_13: I think she uses "the races" as a symbol for risk and luck. People go to the races and place bets on horses; of course, any gambling or betting induces risk or chance of loss. This relates to her relationship, in which she knows there is risk of losing everything, yet she bets everything on it to "win" or get the "prize" of a successful relationship. The lyrics suggest he is a "bad man," with his dark soul and tough nature and all the other one-liners that insinuate danger and an evil nature. She lists everything bad about him, and yet se still loves him clearly, which is a common theme in all of her music--loving someone completely, regardless of his obvious flaws. I LOVE the flow of this song--the rhythm, how she sings the words, how they all flow so well and rhyme and everything. Casino, races, Las Vegas etc. are all references to betting/gambling, or things that may harm her in the end. She goes for it anyway, she "trusts in the decision of the lord." The song is also rather sexual, as he obviously has a very firm "hold" and "grab" on her, and the "light of my life, fire of my loins." This isn't the only reference to Lolita on the album, which also describes an older, dangerous man. but as Lana has said, danger = interest. A safe love would be boring. The chorus shows a duality to her character: the innocent outward appearance ("singing in the garden") matched with the inward, actual dangerous/crazy/naughty personality. There are lots of references and objects so as to give the listener a clear picture in his/her mind. Throughout the song, she is never unsure of her feelings for him, and the end sums up her positivity: "Love you forever, not maybe--you are my one true love." Her chances of a happy relationship may be risky and slim, but her love for him--for better or worse--is absolutely definite.
comment_14:
I like this song over the others on the new album because .... 

the words and interpretation sound like a galloping horse, they move and remind me of the up and down movement of a horse running in a race. Chuck Berry used to write songs with alliteration and rhymes that create a rhythm an a beat that I am crazy for.  there is a glut of song writers out there today who suck at writing songs. Hoagy Charmichal wrote songs as well that rhymed, touched a persons heart and swang to a beat. 

Then the words in this song paint mental images of a sex kitten who is a bad girl but wants to be loved... which is very seductive, especially when she hits the "lot" sound in harlot ... makes an old man weak,,, 

those things are cool but the alliteration and rhyme scheme makes this song have a hook I can't get out of my head.

and I love a good hook
comment_15:
It sounds like a nice and unhealthy relationship where he is probably a gangster boss with loads of money and she is a pretty young thing that is emotionally unstable - she's the only one who will put up with who he really is (a hard criminal) because she realizes nobody else would put up with her antics. 

The "my old man" part obviously refers to the fact that the man is older than the girl, but I'm still a bit uncomfortable with that to be honest, as "my old man" is not a common reference for a partner of ANY age, it's used as an exclusive reference to a father... so it sounded incestuous to me at first. Then I realized it must also be daddy issues (beside excessive drinking, dramatic/extreme behaviors and also borderline criminal).
comment_16: This song is not about Lolita, it is about Humbert Humbert from the perspective of Delores. It's done beautifully.
comment_17: The phrase "glimmering darling" is also from Lolita.
comment_18:
This song seems to be about a young girl who is in love with a much older man ("my old man"- often used to refer to fathers) who abuses her, and as others have said it heavily references "Lolita". 
Some lines also may indicate he is pimping her out, making her stay by exploiting her feelings for him (pimps often try to claim they love the girls to stop them running away) :
 "Gimme them gold coins"- she has to give him money she earns from prostitution."

" 'Cause he knows I'm wasted,
Facing time again at Riker's Island"- he feeds her drug/drink habit and threatens with turning her into the police

"tell me you own me"- she couldn't leave even if she wanted to

"Cigar lying with your gold chain on
Cigar of hanging from your lips"- stereotypically this is what pimps/gangsters look like.
comment_19: I think she's comparing her romance to the of the one in the book Lolita (which by the way is a disturbing story about pedophilia and manipulation and I'd like everybody to stop romanticizing/fetishizing it), and he's a much older man, the speaker is barely 18 and the man is like 40, maybe she is in a situation where she has no parents around or a way to support herself and this dude is her sugar daddy, and anyway he's a criminal of some sort, maybe he sells drugs, and he buys her things in exchange for her affection.
comment_21: I think this is about how she has an older boyfriend that is rich and doesn't care what she did in the past, he wants her for her looks and she knows it but she's enjoying all of the glitz and glamour that goes along with being with him. Such a great tune.
